title: no airport checks uk passengers international travel
story: PASSENGERS at airports around the world face mandatory coronavirus measures such as temperature checks and quarantines - but not in Britain. Hundreds of flights a week are still bringing people into the UK, and an Oxford University study revealed Britain is the only country without government backed coronavirus checks for arrivals or border closures.Foreign Office chiefs are urging against all but essential travel - but people can still freely come and go from the UK.And this week Prime Minister Boris Johnson unveiled plans for a mandatory two week quarantine for travelers which will begin in June.People who fail to obey will be subject o £, fines or deportation - but critics have said it is too late.Transport secretary Grant Shapps also hinted airport screening will be introduced while speaking in April - saying it must be part of the plan going forward.And also last month, health secretary Matt Hancock admitted at least , people were flying into the UK daily without being screened for coronavirus.The UK is already the second most impacted nation in the world from the virus, with more than , deaths.Flights this week have arrived from Europes other two worst impacted nations - Italy and Spain - and China, where the virus is believed to have originated in late .Gatwick and Heathrow Airports bosses have previously called for some kind of mandatory measures to be introduced to help combat the virus.Oxford Universitys Blavatnik School of Government found the UK was the only country known to not be practicing any restrictions, reports the .Elsewhere in the world, travelers face tough restrictions to try and control the virus - such as these here.Travelers arriving in Spain have to quarantine themselves at an address for  days - with all inessential international travel into the country banned until at least June .Passengers arriving at airports are met by health officials who administer temperature checks and registers arrivals, taking down the address they will be isolating at for the next two weeks.Those travelling also must wear face masks and follow social distancing, and they must also arrive at airports no earlier than  minutes before their flight.Spanish nationals are the only people who canto Spain, unless they have residence, are cross border workers, or are passing through to get home - such as a connecting flight.The country has the second highest case count in the world, with the fourth highest death toll - with , and ,.Spain remains in a state of emergency, which was first declared on March .However despite plans to lt restrictions, foreign minister Arancha Gonzalez Laya has admitted tourists may not be welcome tountil the start of .Pictures show French airports have rolled out technology such as thermal cameras to check on arrivals as they come through airports.Air France has also said it will ban passengers it deems to unfit to fly and will be checking passengers temperatures.Government restrictions are also in place on who can come in - and people have to wear masks at airports.Only those from the  Schengen states, British passport holders and French citizens or residents are allowed to enter France.Those who are travelling from outside of the borders - which are closed aside from for repatriation -  must quarantine themselves for  days.People travelling within the European Union do not have to quarantine.Italy is due to begin easing its travel restrictions as a part of a plan to use tourism to help jump start the economy - with the country being the first in Europe to feel the full force of the virus.But until June , travelers are still facing a mandatory quarantine of  days when they arrive.Thermal scanners and temperatures checks are also present at some airports, occasionally manned by military officials to spot anyone suffering from Covid-.Anyone arriving in the country also currently must self-certy and report to health officials when they arrive.Passengers must have a form which details exactly why they are arriving in Italy.Germany previously had restrictions at the border with anyone entering the country told they had to have urgent reason to do so.Residents, citizens or long-term visa holders were continued to be allowed in.Passengers arriving from China, Iran, Italy, Japan and South Korea have also previously been told to provide information about their trip on a disembarkation card.However, as of this week travel restrictions have been loosened and land borders reopened with Austria, France and Switzerland.Screening will continued to be carried out however for the virus - with Germany having one of the lowest death rates in Europe with , fatalities from , cases.Greece has extended its flight bans to the United Kingdom, Italy, the Netherlands, Spain, North Macedonia, Turkey and Albania.It also has in place a ban on the entry of non-EU nationals until May  - except for those in Schengen countries and so-called third citizens of the EU.Flights to Britain are suspended until May  - and all international flights until then will have to land at Athens International Airport.It comes as Greece has begun reopening its beaches as it remains hopeful it will be able to cash in on the tourist season.The country has just , cases and  deaths.Greece is also planning to reopen six land border crossings which had been closed due to the coronavirus.Hong Kong has completely closed its borders to anyone who is not a resident or citizen.The measures however seem to be working, having just , coronavirus cases and four deaths from its population of .million.Everyone arriving must provide proof of their residence or citizenship and complete a form about their health.And anyone who has been outside the country, must be quarantined for  days, wear a tracking device on their wrist and download an app that will track their whereabouts.If they are found to have symptoms, passengers will be sent to the Department of Health who will decide what to do next.Tests are administered by deep throat saliva samples and take eight hours to process - with passengers having to be bused to a hotel to wait for their results.Pictures also show airport workers going through full-body disinfectant cabinets - which cleaning robots use UV lights to disinfect the terminals.The US is the worst hit country in the world by the coronavirus, with almost .million cases and , deaths.And this is despite travel restrictions being introduced early - closing the borders to any foreign nationals who had visited China in February.Tough measures have since been ramped up, with all travel from the UK, China, Iran, Ireland and the Schengen zone completely banned.US citizens and green card holders who have been to these areas must report to one of the  airports and provide details of their medical history.They also must self isolate for  days upon ing home.Vending machines have also been in place at some airports selling PPE for passengers.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boy escaping abusive parents forgot handcuff him
story: The -year-old was found on a lonely rural highway in Missouri the middle of the night, emaciated and covered in bruises.He told the Missouri State Highway Patrol trooper who found him that he packed a bag and fled his house.According to court documents, biological dad Christopher, , and -year-old step-mom Nicole Crets forgot to handcuff him to his bed that day.Both were charged with felony child abuse on May  and Christopher Crets is also charged with kidnapping along with four counts of unlawful possession of a firearm.Warren County Sherf Kevin Harrison said it was a “miracle” the boy wasn’t seriously hurt – either on the road or by his parents.“He’s very fortunate, hes walking in traffic, he’s just wanting somebody to stop and help them and a state trooper just happened to be the car coming down the highway,” Harrison told KSDK.“It just was an answered prayer for him. It was definitely this boys time to be rescued.His eyes were swollen, his forehead was swollen, this boy was beaten and tortured at the hands of mom and dad so Im very happy that he slipped out.”He added he was “glad the trooper was there and that my detectives and deputies were able to be part of rescuing him from the situation”.It breaks my heart because theres this child is being handcuffed in his own home, and hes being not just abused, but tortured by his parents, said Harrison.The boy told police he once weighed  to  pounds but was  pounds when authorities took him to the hospital.He was also suffering from refeeding syndrome, which is a metabolic condition that can cause seizures, heart failure, fatigue and confusion due to starvation.The boy is now protective custody while his parents are in jail awaiting their next court appearance.Detectives who searched the boy’s rural home and found handcuffs attached to the boy’s bed, according to the documents.The boy told police his parents beat him with their bare hands and a belt in abuse that lasted two to three months.According to the local authorities, the child’s parents pulled him out of school about three months ago to homeschool him so teachers were unable to see any signs of abuse.They told police they were keeping the boy restrained because he was “sneaking” food and candy.The couple claim they were trying to prevent him from eating certain foods because he has a medical condition.They are now at the Warren County jail and due to appear in court again on May .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rich kind joe wicks inspiring mum
story: If he wasn’t already a household name before this began, Joe, with his spontaneous and generous offer of a daily free PE class, has certainly become one now.A whopping million people tuned in during the first week. He has stuck to his promise and shown up every day, despite having to have surgery on his wrist and being in evident pain at times.Not only that, but he is donating the revenue from advertising on the show to the NHS. He embodies the perfect combination of qualities required to be a good business person: Do all you can, give something back and be ethical.In the past six weeks he has made more than £.million as new fans snapped up his -Day Plan well-being programme from his Body Coach site.But I really don’t think this was about making more money or becoming more famous.Bear in mind that Joe, who is only , has already made millions following the success of his cookbook and his online fitness classes.He really didn’t need to make more money or be more famous.I honestly believe he just wants children everywhere to experience the joy of fitness.There is a lot to like about Joe. But one thing I love about him is that one of his first le goals was to buy his mum, Raquela, a house. Having grown up on a council estate in Surrey, with Raquela and brothers Nikki and George, Joe always dreamed of being able to spend his earnings on his mum after she supported him in the earliest days of his career.“My mum’s always lived in a council house. We’ve never had mortgages. It wasn’t on the radar for us.“So when I could take that money I earned from that book and say ‘Mum, I’m buying your house. It’s yours’, that was an amazing moment for me.”Joe didn’t have an easy childhood. He has spoken about his father Gary still struggling with heroin addiction. But rather than repeating history, he actively decided to take a dferent path.He found exercise as a coping method. “I used exercise probably as a way to manage my feelings,” he has said.He said: “Because of my dad’s addiction, and the damage I saw it cause, me and Nikki steered clear of it. We weren’t smoking weed. We were training, exercising and playing sport. Along the line, I decided that wasn’t going to be my destiny.”Things in le either crush you or make you the person you were always meant to be. The strength of character it takes to turn your back on the path chosen by your first and most important role model — your dad — is immense.It would be so easy for him to have chosen the same path as his father or use his father’s addiction as an excuse for not making the most of his le.Joe has said he tries not to dwell on his past nor judge his dad. All that matters to him now is being happy and looking forward.The moral of this story is: Put the graft in, keep pushing yourself and never give up.But one of the many likeable things about Joe is how readily he credits Raquela for her role in his success, saying she taught them “right and wrong”, while his dad was “in and out of rehab”.She must be a hell of a woman to have brought up three boys so well. Joe and Nikki work together now, which is testament to the strength of their family ties.Knowing all this about Joe makes it all the more amazing he found his happy ever after when he married his model we Rosie in , and the pair now have two adorable children — Indie who’s  months and four-month-old Marley.It would be easy to resent his success. But how could anyone wish Joe anything other than happiness, given what he has overcome and also his approach to le I’m as keen as the next person for the lockdown to end and for normal le to resume – at least as much as it possibly can.But when I read about the fliers advertising mass gatherings, promising picnics and live music in cities across the UK this weekend, I couldn’t believe my eyes.At least eight events were being organised by anti-vaxxing group UK Freedom Movement, which claims the lockdown is illegal.Its posters headlined “UK Mass Gathering” said: “We say no to the coronavirus bill, no to mandatory vaccines, no to the new normal and no to the unlawful lockdown.”It is also urged people to gather in a major park in the eight locations, including London, Sheffield and Edinburgh, to “bring a picnic, some music and let’s have some fun and say yes to le”.Yes, lockdown measures are extreme and yes, we all want them to relax and for normality to .But what the organisers of this are failing to realise is that you can’t protest or demonstrate against a virus.And while there is so much still left for us to understand about how this particular virus works, to attend a mass gathering in protest seems like a fool’s errand.This event is clearly organised by idiots, for idiots.If only we’d all been quick-witted enough to self-isolate with someone who knows how to do our hair, like Kate Moss, who has been hunkering down with A-lister stylist James Brown.That said, Kate is an absolute beauty and clearly a supermodel, whether she is having a good hair day or a bad one.As luck would have it I am currently living with my mum.She has done a grand job dyeing my roots so far, but I think a blow-dry may be beyond her remit.Luckily, with a pandemic going on, and staff to worry about, I have more important things to think about than my hair.Twitter has been among the first companies to announce that it will not be bringing employees back into the workplacethey would prefer to work from home.And for more and more people, home is likely to be the new workplace – with meetings taking place on screens.The past few weeks have shown us that as long as people have a laptop and wi-fi, many can work from home.For lots of us, being allowed to do so means we save loads of money on travel and hundreds of hours of commuting time, while massively reducing our carbon footprint.And we’ll never have to buy a stale sandwich again.Meanwhile, companies will save a fortune on rent.All in all, this new way of working, for those who can do it, makes sense.Over the past few weeks we have all become much more aware of people’s proximity to us.And yes, with streets that have fewer cars than ever before, no doubt some of us are stepping into the road to avoid another pedestrian who could come within two metres of us.But police have felt the need to issue warnings to pedestrians not to walk into the road to dodge fellow pedestrians because it is dangerous .Seriously, is such a warning really necessary I know we have all been in lockdown for a while but surely we haven’t taken leave of our common sense and will remember to look left and right when we cross the road . . . won’t we It’s now been eight weeks since our Thursday night Clap For Carers began. And looking at this photo of Boris Johnson outside No from Thursday, it’s a good reminder that things are changing all the time.When you compare it to the picture taken of him just days before he was admitted to hospital it really shows the big dference a few weeks make.He looks more or less back to his old self. Also, it’s really cheering to see new mum Carrie looking so well and so happy.We seem to be seeing lots of people in their swim-wear at the moment, with not a. pool in sight!Normally I try to give thanks for my strong and able body rather than worrying too much about what it looks like.But it’s hard not to feel a tad wistful looking at photos of Kimberley Garner, who looks so fit and gorgeous she’d no doubt be awarded swimwear body of the week,such an award existed. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: kids lunchbox school pencil case

I know this is the plan.The announcement arrives amidst a fiery row between unions and government ministers over the plannedof schools, set to potentially go ahead this June.Education Secretary Gavin Williamson confirmed the government is pushing on with plans for pupils in Reception, Years , ,  and  toas early as next month.He also revealed that pupils in Year  and Year  will be back on a limited basis to help them plan for exams next year.Mr Williamson said schools would only rates of infection continue to decrease and therefore give the green light.Unions, however, are vehemently opposed to the plan, and claim that teachers, pupils and their families will be at risk of catching the deadly virus.Mr Williamson has warned teaching unions of consequences of schools not reopening.It comes as:He said: The longer the schools are closed, the more the children miss out. title: kids get coronavirus jenny harries
story: KIDS are just as likely as adults to contract coronavirus, but dont get as ill, according to Deputy Chief Medical Officer Jenny Harries. Speaking at the Downing Street press briefing this evening, Dr. Harries said younger children could also be less likely to pass the virus on.Dr. Harries said: There are two groups that are at potential risk here, one are children.We think that children probably have the same level of infection, we are just going through that data now with the ONS survey, but they dont get as ill.We rarely see children in hospital in proportion to the older population.And for younger children as well, the evidence is still growing but there may be some evidence that they are less likely to pass it on.When asked about teachers ing to classrooms, she said: For teachers, again it’s dficult because we’ve had lockdown butyou look at the ONS death rates, the teaching profession is very low in comparison to a number of other professions or work areas.I think we’ve got a number of signals that say this is a safe place to go. I think parents and teachers should not be thinking that every school is swarming with cases, we are moving in quite a dferent direction now.Dr Harries said the idea is to have little groups in the classroom where you increase the level of interaction a small amount, but it is contained.Social interactions among older children is more likely to affect the R value than simply going back to school, deputy chief medical officer Jenny Harries said.Speaking at the daily Downing Street briefing, she said: The model thats been adopted, the suggestion for younger children to go back to school, is not just because of the school environment but its about the behaviours that go with it.If you pull back a whole load of older children, they tend to get on buses, travel longer distances, have dferent social interactions.And some of those social interactions are actually far more signicant in moving the R value than just going back to school.Unions are opposed to the plan and have warned classes may not resume until September.They have asked the government to urgently publish the scientic evidence behind the decision to reopen Englands schools to more pupils from June .A survey for the Office for National Statistics of , people has found no evidence of dferences between age groups in those who tested positive.The number of those testing positive for coronavirus is between . and . per cent across all ages.Simon Clarke, associate professor in cellular microbiology of the University of Reading, who was not part of the ONS project, said: We have a horrible choice ahead of us with reopening schools.Back when we first started learning about this virus, we knew from China that children did not seem to be so affected. That leads to two questions. The first is whether they get the virus. And now we know that yes, they do. The second is whether they transmit it. We dont know the answer to that.Last month a study by the Royal College of Paediatricians and Child Health, found children do not play a signicant role in spreading the deadly virus.They said the evidence consistently demonstrates reduced infection and infectivity of children in the transmission chain.And there has not been a single case of a child under  passing on coronavirus in contact tracing carried out by the World Health Organisation.However there are reports some kids suffer a rare inflammatory syndrome weeks after being infected with Covid-.In a very small number of children it can cause serious complications, with some needing intensive care.Up to  children in the UK have been affected and studies suggest the same reaction is being seen in kids where in Europe.It is likely to be caused by a delayed immune response to the virus which looks like Kawasaki disease.Council leaders have said schools should be allowed to make their owns decisions about reopening - especially in areas where there is a higher proportion of black, Asian and minority ethnic residents.That comes after analysis by the Office for National Statistics suggested black men and women are more than four times more likely to die from coronavirus than white people.The government has faced increasing pressure from union leaders and MPs to release the science behind its plans to get kids back in schools.Osama Rahman, chief scientic adviser at the Department for Education, said there was a low degree of confidence in evidence suggesting children transmit Covid- less than adults.Former Labour education secretary Lord Blunkett yesterday said he was surprised by union leaders attitude towards reopening schools.He said: I am being deeply critical of the attitude. Its about how can we work together to make it work as safely as possible. Anyone who works against that in my view is working against the interests of children.Education Secretary Gavin Williamson said: When you have medical and scientic advice that is saying its the right time to start bringing schools back in a phased and controlled manner, it seems only the right thing to do and the only responsible thing to do.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: beauty spot car parks close brits seaside lockdown eased
story: CAR parks at beauty spots were forced to close as thousands of Brits flocked to the seaside following the easing of lockdown restrictions.Changes in the Covid- regulations since Wednesday mean people in England can now drive to outdoor open spaces irrespective of distance - so long as they do not travel into Wales or Scotland.Pictures show visitors piling onto Dorsets famous Durdle Door beach to sunbathe in the balmy weather, leading to full car parks.A number of car parks in Dartmoor, Devon were also forced to close after becoming too crowded, local authorities confirmed.An email sent out by the Dartmoor ranger team revealed the news, explaining that it was making social distancing impossible.The email read: As of : car parks in the Haytor, Postbridge and Newbridge area are now too busy for social distancing to be observed.Please can potential visitors to Dartmoor avoid these areas.People headed to Brighton Beach and Whitley Bay, while others enjoyed a game of tennis for the first time in two months.Police were also seen carrying out spot checks on those flocking to Brighton.As thousands rushed to the coast, police carried out a number of road safety checks in the Brighton area.A spokesman for Sussex Police told Sun Online: With an increase in vehicles on our countys roads, it is paramount we ensure the safety of all road users, as well as remaining committed to preventing criminals the use of our roads.The Road Traffic Act  provides police with the power to stop vehicles for any reason.The easing of the Covid- lockdown in England means people can drive as far as they want to exercise outdoors, as long as they do not spend the night away from their home.Several tourist boards had urged people to stay away due to fears they will be overwhelmed by visitors.But while  million Brits were predicted to descend on beauty spots, traffic increased just % on last Saturday as many chose to remain at home.However scores of people travelled to popular spots despite being asked to think carefully before visiting national parks and beaches.The Peak District National Park said the Langsett area at the north-eastern edge of the park was extremely busy on Saturday morning, making social distancing dficult.A number of Dartmoor car parks were also closed as they became too crowded.The Yorkshire Dales introduced a traffic light system to let visitors know how busy its car parks are in  dferent locations.By Saturday afternoon, its Malham car park, which has  spaces, was marked red to indicate it was full, while other locations were marked amber to show they were filling up fast.James Mason, chief executive of Welcome to Yorkshire, said: Many of these places have ageing populations who need protecting.If youre travelling more than - miles is it really necessary  Wed say Dream about it, explore later.Julian German, the leader of Cornwall council, added: We have been really clear alongside government that people shouldnt be coming to Cornwall on holiday and that its totally inappropriate.The minor changes in policy that happened this week dont change that and were not open for tourism.Yesterday Airbnb extended its restrictions on bookings until the end of this month.In some areas, locals councils have told outsiders they are not welcome and there were fears people arriving in large numbers could result in vigilante attacks.Cleveland Police put out a warning to the public after a number of nail traps were found hidden in Guisborough Woods, a popular spot for walkers.Similar traps made of drawing pins were found on paths near Bournemouth in Dorset yesterday.Martin Hewitt, chairman of the National Police Chiefs Council, issued a plea asking them to consider whether it was really worthwhile.He said: All I would ask is that anybody who is planning to travel to a beauty spot, be respectful to the communities while you are there.Be respectful for the environment while you are there and obviously think about whether you want to go to places that are going to be very, very busy because that will inevitably make social distancing more challenging for you.He added: Think about what travel and what activities you are going to undertake outside and try still to be sensible about what you do when you are out.Maintain the two-metre distance at all times where that is possible and generally put yourself in a place where you can maintain that distance because that is what will stop you being infected or stop you infecting anyone . To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Our title: sir jim ratcliffe furlough hotel staff
story: ONE of Britain’s richest men is using taxpayer money to furlough nearly  staff at his luxury hotel chain.Sir Jim Ratclfe, who’s worth £.billion and once tried to buy Cha Football Club, is using the scheme to pay workers up to £,-a-month.The Home Grown Hotels and Lime Wood Group venues are favourites of celebrities, and hosted the weddings of Noel Gallagher and Jamie Cullum.Tory MP Peter Bone said: “People will find it dficult to understand why the ultra-rich are sponging off the taxpayer.“Many of my constituents would think they should be paying the wages and not the taxpayer.”Sir Jim, , is fth in the new Sunday Times Rich List — topped by Sir James Dyson and family with the Hinduja family second.Last year it was reported Sir Jim was drawing up plans to move to Monaco to save up to £billion in tax.Two years ago he bid £billion for Cha but was rebuffed by Russian owner Roman Abramovich.Sir Jim, who owns chemical giant Ineos, spends £million a year backing F team Mercedes and sponsors cycling racers Team Ineos, formerly Team Sky.He is the majority owner of the hotel chain.Chief executive and chairman Robin Hutson wrote on the company website: “The furlough scheme and the Coronavirus Business Interruption Loan Schemehave undoubtedly prevented signicant job loss. My company alone has  staff furloughed and has secured four million in CBILS, for which we are thankful.”The Government announced their job retention scheme at the end of March as lockdown hit businesses.Chancellor Rishi Sunak outlined how firms could furlough staff, with the Government paying  per cent of their monthly wage up to £,.Employers can top that up furtherthey wish.Around a quarter of the UK workforce is covered by the furlough system, costing around £.billion per month.Last week, The Sun on Sunday revealed the Hinduja family, who are worth £billion, were also using the scheme at bus making subsidiary company Optare.Meanwhile, Victoria Beckham’s fashion business, plus Liverpool and Tottenham football clubs, have reversed decisions to furlough staff after a public backlash.A spokesman for Sir Jim said: “The hotels business is following Government guidelines and as soon as it is allowed to re-open, it will. We plan to retain all hotel staff.“The group is supplementing wages and has been since day one of the lockdown.Last week it was the £billion Hinduja brothers. This week we reveal that hotelier Sir Jim Ratclfe, worth an estimated £billion, is also at it.Despite his wealth, Sir Jim is happy to use the public purse to foot the bill.Perhaps these billionaires regard their behaviour as normal.To every normal person it is an outrage.“Those that continue to be able to work in the hotels group maintain the facilities and kitchen gardens, producing food for local people and NHS workers.”Ineos has not furloughed any of its , staff at its chemical sites across the UK.The company, which also has plants in the US and Europe, has been producing medical-grade hand sanitiser, vital drugs, reagent chemicals that go into testing kits and plastics needed for medical equipment during the pandemic. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: vaccine development hub open 2021
story: Construction of a new dedicated centre is  months ahead of schedule and will have the ability to produce enough vaccines for the entire population in just six months.The new Vaccine Manufacturing and Innovation Centre based in Oxfordshire to open next year will also help increase the long-term capacity against any future viruses.It will also help produce jabs for existing illnesses including the flu virus. story: The urgent plans emerged following Education Secretary Gavin Williamson’s row with teaching unions holding up ato the classroom.The aim is to assist kids who teachers feel have lost out by not attending class since late March due to Covid-.It would be the first time since World War Two that pupils will have gone to school in the summer break.At yesterday’s Downing Street press conference, Mr Williamson said: “We’re looking at dferent initiatives that we could maybe look at rolling out during the summer period.”He confirmed ministers are going ahead with plans to get some primary pupils back to school on June , saying: “We owe it to the children.”And in a thinly-veiled attack on the unions, minister Mr Williamson added: “There is a consequence to this, the longer the schools close the more children miss out.“Teachers know that there are children out there that have not spoken or played with another child their own age for the last two months.”He spoke as the first weekend since the easing of lockdown and travel restrictions was put under strain as people flock to beaches and parks.But some day trippers were left confused by the latest social distancing rules.Yesterday the daily Covid- death toll figure rose by , taking the total to ,.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: voice sunday mirror need leader
story: NewsopinionVoice of the Sunday Mirror: We need a leader not a lightweight blusterer like BorisBoris Johnson is now being exposed for the lightweight he is. A cheeky smile and a ready joke are no substitute for the competent leadership Britain needs at a time of perilShareCommentsByVoice of the Mirror:,  MAY NewsopinionBritains Prime Minister Boris Johnson " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailBoris Johnson is living on borrowed time. The Prime Minister may have survived Covid-, but the British people will not forgive him for the way the disease has engulfed the nation. In an exclusive Sunday Mirror poll today,  per cent of voters blame the Government for the highest death toll in Europe, and one in three of those cites the PM’s poor leadership. When specic health advice is called for, he rambles. When a straight answer is needed, he blusters. We get confusion when clarity is most required. Mr Johnson has shed some pounds since his illness and as PM he is now being exposed for the lightweight he is. A cheeky smile and a ready joke are no substitute for the competent leadership Britain needs at a time of peril like no other since the Second World War. The grotesque chaos in our care homes has left at least , dead. Health Secretary Matt Hancock must shoulder responsibility for the failure to test and the lack of PPE which caused that. When the care sector desperately needs money just to survive, it is not getting through. Local Government Secretary Robert Jenrick is responsible for that. First Secretary Dominic Raab and Transport Secretary Grant Shapps are bargain-basement barrow boys, Home Secretary Priti Patel is merely second-rate and only Rishi Sunak has emerged with any sign of sure feet.  No wonder the Chancellor is being talked up as Boris Johnson’s replacement. Because it is with the PM that the buck stops. We now know that he ordered lockdown too late, and unease is growing that he is lting it too early. Only one in five of those questioned in our poll thinks it safe for children toto school next month. And it is telling that the UK is no longer united as the devolved administrations choose to move at dferent speeds. That shows how confidence in our leader is ebbing away. We accept that dealing with a novel virus would test any government. We appreciate that Mr Johnson has probably not fully recovered from his own brush with death. But when thousands of lives depend on his decisions, what we get is not good enough. We endure minister after minister telling us at the daily No update how clever they are.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Natalie Poole arrived on the remote island of Kyun Pila in Myanmar on March  and planned to spend the next month working as a volunteer to help protect a coral reef - but then coronavirus hit.The -year-old, from Ashburton in Devon, is now trapped in a real le castaway drama after her only boat off the island was cancelled as Myanmar and nearby Thailand both went into lockdown. For the last two months, Natalie and four other volunteers have been forced to survive almost without any aid in one of the worldaposs most remote locations. Natalie and her fellow volunteers were due to be rescued on May  but were left devastated again when their boat was cancelled after Thailand extended its lockdown. The scuba er instructor, who should be back in Devon by now and working as a summer school teacher, is hopeful another boat will arrive to collect them later this month. However, her visa has expired and no new ones are being issued while the coronavirus pandemic holds the world in its grip. Natalie said: The hardest thing for me has been not knowing how long weaposre going to be here. Itaposs kind of up and down, weaposre a very small group of people and weaposre living in a very confined, close situation. In the back of our minds is obviously families back home and stuff, which adds to the tension a little bit. Weaposre just trying to take things day by day. But for now, the tiny group have had to do what they can to survive, using washed up bits of plastic to make their rainforest camp. They share the island with scorpions, snakes, mouse-deer, wild boar, monitor lizards, and slow lorises, and have to forage for most of their food, including yams, jackfruit and other vegetation. There have been sporadic deliveries by boat of food staples, including rice and pasta. But the group are conscious they have to make sure these last as they donapost know when the next one will arrive - and there have been plenty of days where they have gone hungry. Natalie said: We have to be very aware of how much we consume, we are eating very basic food and really having to make it last. Despite the desperate situation the group, which is made up of two women and three men from England, Hungary, Canada, Malaysia and France, find themselves in - they are not totally alone. There is one resort on Kyun Pila, Awei Pila, which is a  minute dinghy sail away and where they can access water, showers and accomodation on portable cabins, as well as a patchy wi signal. This has proved a leline for Natalie, who is concerned for her -year-old father, who lives in Poole in the UK. But the group, who are volunteers with environmental group Ocean Quest Global, have had to adapt quickly to spending so much extra time on the island. Their jungle camp has been constructed from washed up plastic, with each person living in a hut made from bamboo, rice sacks and bottles. They have even managed to erect furniture in their new Robinson Crusoe-inspired le, have dug a well, a fire pit and place to wash.The volunteers have also started planting their own vegetables. There are other challenges for the small group, existing in such extreme circumstances. Natalie explained: Usually in a programme like this there is a regular change of volunteers, which keeps things fresh and interesting, but the other three volunteers have been with each other a long time now and relationships are strained at times. Communal living is always a challenge because you get so little personal space and have to compromise a great deal. One person’s negative attitude or bad mood will affect everyone. The group has been forced to adapt to their change in circumstances, with people learning to hack jungle trails, drive a dingy and build with bamboo. Natalie has earned herself the nickname Trash Squirrel by spending her days combing the beach for washed up waste that can then be put to use to build the structures theyaposre calling home and to be turned into useful tools for surivival. But as spring slowly turns into summer Natalie and her fellow volunteers are facing a new challenge - the tropical rainy season. Already the clouds are coming in faster and the first few drops of rain have started to fall. They are working to do all they can to ensure they are as ready as possible for when the downpours do come.  However, Natalie is still hopeful that a rescue boat will come for them before the rainy season begins in earnest. She says it has also been a useful time for getting to know herself better. Natalie explained: I learned that no matter how Zen and chilled I had thought I was, in moments of solitude and dficult moments of physical and mental tiredness, I still lose control and stop being mindful and calm. That no matter how friendly and cheerful I usually am, when I am locked down on a relatively small island with strangers, I become moody, grumpy and little motivated.

And three quarters of those say it should be permanent. A Sunday Mirror poll by Redfield  Wilton Strategies found  per cent of those questioned say our healthcare heroes deserve the increase.Nearly three quarters of Britain’s voters say the country could have avoided having the highest coronavirus death toll in Europe. And  per cent of those say Boris Johnson ’s poor leadership is to blame for the disease’s spread, although an overall  per cent think there was a collective failure by MPs, ministers, officials and scientic advisers.The top three reasons people gave for the , deaths at care homes were the lack of personal protective equipment, too little testing, and not locking down the UK early enough. Plans to open schools to some children next month are unpopular, with only one in five believing it is safe. More than half think lockdown is being lted too quickly and  per cent say Boris Johnson added to confusion over the new rules. Nearly one in four would be very nervous about ing to normal activities next month, and fewer than one in three of us would be confident doing so by September. Half of Brits won’t be happy to resume their usual activities until newly confirmed coronavirus cases fall below  a day.  Nearly three quarters want the law changed so bosses have to give staff the option to work from home once lockdown lts. And more than three quarters would like to see videolink consultations with GPs continue.  While  per cent say masks should be compulsory on public transport, more than eight in  reckon workers should be encouraged to walk, cycle or drive to avoid buses and trains.The Queen and Rishi Sunak have improved their reputations with their responses to the pandemic.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA vaccine to end the pandemic is just months away – and it will be created in Britain, claims TV doctor Michael Mosley. The award-winning documentary-maker was given access to the top-security Porton Down laboratory where vaccines from two of our top universities are being tested. Michael told the Sunday Mirror: “Everybody is moving ahead with the belief we’ll have a vaccine by the end of the year. The speed at which it’s happening is astonishing as vaccines normally take five to  years.” Michael, , met Miles Carroll, deputy director of the National Infection Service at Public Health England, at the sprawling base in Salisbury, Wilts, for a BBC Horizon special. Researchers there are looking at vaccines produced by Oxford University and Imperial College London. A million doses of Oxford’s vaccine could be ready as early as September.  Around , people will take part in its trial, half receiving the vaccine and the other half receiving a meningitis vaccine, and results are expected to begin to emerge next month.AstraZeneca, the Cambridge-based pharmaceutical group, is teaming up with Oxford University to manufacture and distribute the vaccineclinical trials are positive. Michael, who created the : diet, said: “Our own scientists are storming ahead. It’s brilliant. They got the funding and the scientists were there to rock and roll.  “The Americans and Chinese are amongst the leaders but British vaccine leaders are at the forefront. One scientist I spoke to this week was confident at least one vaccine will be available this year.” Scientists at the centre also trialled the Roche antibody tests, which they judged to be % accurate. That is now being rolled out across the country and is seen as key to getting the nation back to work. Michael said: “Porton Down is one of the few places you can test these things.  They have the live virus down there. It’s odd when you see them in their hoods and protective clothing. “The thing that’s causing all these problems is right there. They’re manipulating it and testing it right in front of you. It’s strange being so close to something which is causing distress around the planet.” Michael was last at the site in  for a BBC show. He said: “Back then they were talking about the risk of a pandemic exactly like this one. People have been worrying about it for years.”  Michael said authorities were caught out by the pandemic after previous outbreaks such as SARS and MERS were contained in Asia and the Middle East and did not affect the UK. “People got complacent,” he said. “So when Covid happened we were ill-prepared.” And he fears there are more outbreaks ahead, adding: “The rate these viruses are emerging is accelerating. There’s no doubt in my mind there are others coming down the track. Hopefully lessons have been learnt and we’ll be better prepared for next time.” But other scientists say a vaccine is unlikely to be available for general use before .  Business Secretary Alok Sharma is spending £million to speed up the building of a vaccine manufacturing centre on the Harwell Science and Innovation Campus in Oxfordshire. But he will say today that although it will come on stream a year earlier than planned, it will not open until next summer. Any vaccine will take at least six months to produce after that. There are  research projects worldwide using £million of UK funding. Eight are now using people for clinical tests. But most experts predict vaccine discovery to be a year to  months away.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailDficulty speaking could be a aposseriousapos symptom of coronavirus, experts have warned. Currently, the NHS say a persistent cough and a fever are the two main Covid- symptons. However, people diagnosed with the virus have complained of other symptoms, with a loss of speech a possible sign of the disease. Experts at the World Health Organisationsaid dficulty speaking could be accompanied by a lack of movement, and anyone experiencing these symptoms should see a doctor. The WHO said: Most people infected with the COVID- virus will experience mild to moderate respiratory illness and recover without requiring special treatment. Serious symptoms: Dficulty breathing or shortness of breath, chest pain or pressure, loss of speech or movement. Seek immediate medical attentionyou have serious symptoms. Always call before visiting your doctor or health facility. But, a loss of speech may not necessarily always be a sign of coronavirus. Speaking dficulties could also be a sign of other medical or psychological conditions, such as hearing loss, hearing problems, certain toxins, or selective mutism. Earlier this week, a new study highlighted another, lesser-known symptom - psychosis.  Researchers at Orygen and La Trobe University in Melbourne have warned that coronavirus is causing psychotic episodes for some patients. Dr  Ellie Brown, co-lead author of the study, said: “COVID- is a very stressful experience for everyone, particularly those with complex mental health needs.“We know that psychosis, and first episodes of psychosis, are commonly triggered by substantial psychosocial stresses. In the context of COVID-, this could include stress relating to isolation and having to potentially remain within challenging family situations.” In the study, the team looked at research on viruses such as MERS as SARS, to examinethere was a connection on how these viruses might impact people with psychosis. The results suggest that some coronavirus patients may experience psychotic symptoms, such as hearing voices. Professor Richard Gray, co-lead author of the study, said: “Maintaining infection control procedures when people are psychotic is challenging. “In order for them not to become potential transmitters of the virus, clinicians and service providers may benefit from specic infection control advice to mitigate any transmission risk.” While mental health disorders such as depression and anxiety are already being focused on amid the pandemic, the researchers hope their findings will spark further research into more severe mental health conditions like psychosis. Professor Gray added: “This is a group thataposs probably going to need more support, with isolation, physical distancing, hand washing etc, and clinicians may be the ones who need to be thinking and working on this to assist this vulnerable population.

story: NewsFamily plead with Crossbow Cannibal to tell them where their loved one is buriedEXCLUSIVE Susan Rushworth was murdered by evil Stephen Grfiths  years ago but hes still never revealed where her remains areShareCommentsByPhil Cardy:,  MAY NewsCrossbow cannibal Stephen Grfiths " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailFor more than  years the ­family of murdered Susan Rushworth have pleaded with one of Britain’s most chilling killers to end their living hell. But evil Stephen Grfiths, who shot his prostitute victims with a crossbow before chopping them up and eating their flesh, still won’t tell them where her remains are. Susan’s killing not only plunged her family into unimaginable grief, it sent her vulnerable daughter Kirsty spiralling into prostitution and drugs as she struggled to cope with the loss of her mum. This week – a decade on from the Crossbow Cannibal killings that shocked the nation – her son James told how the anniversary had rekindled all their ­despair at not knowing where Susan is, and how they have given up hope Grfiths will tell them. “The police have told us to write to him and ask him where mum’s body is – but it’s not going to happen is it  It’s a joke, isn’t it. He won’t do the decent thing,” said James, .  And his -year-old gran Christine fears she will go to her grave never knowing where her daughter lies. Mum-of-three Susan, , was the first of uni student Grfiths’ three known victims. The killing spree at his seedy flat on the edge of Bradford’s red-light district made headlines worldwide. He later confessed to police he took apart his victims’ bodies with a hunting kne in the bath after shooting them with his crossbow. He ate some of their flesh before dumping the remains. Susan was last seen getting off a bus in June . Detectives later found traces of her blood in the flat. In April , Grfiths – who was completing a PhD in homicide studies at the city’s university – struck a second time. He shot Shelley Armitage, , another sex worker, and dismembered her – even filming his crime on his phone while commentating on it. He then used public transport to move her body parts in bin bags so he could dispose of them. In May  he killed his final victim, Suzanne Blamires, , who he kidnapped and held in his flat for two days before she made a desperate attempt to escape. Chilling CCTV footage in the corridor outside his flat showed him executing the prostitute with a crossbow bolt. Then he brazenly strolled up to the camera and made a one-fingered gesture. Police were alerted after a horried caretaker viewed the footage. When they arrived at his flat, he was calmly waiting to be taken into custody. He told officers he had eaten parts of his victims, declaring he “didn’t have much time for the human race”. Grfiths, then , said he had killed “loads of women” and even compared himself to Yorkshire Ripper Peter Sutclfe who murdered . Body parts found in the River Aire, in Shipley, near Bradford, were identied as Suzanne’s.  Other human tissue found in the same river was later established as belonging to Shelley. But no remains of Susan have ever been found. Her distraught daughter Kirsty has revealed she sent a letter to the killer asking where her mum was so she could have a proper funeral – but never got a reply. In a cruel twist, she found herself sucked into the world of prostitution and drugs, haunted by loss of her mother. Several years after the murder Kirsty, now , described herself as Grfiths’ “fourth victim” as she worked the same street corners as her mum to feed her habit. But now her protective big brother James says she had thankfully turned her le around and is doing well. He said: “It’s all sorted. She’s all right. She’s with us.” James said his gran Christine couldn’t face talking about the loss of her daughter again.But she also has previously pleaded with Grfiths to tell her what he did with Susan’s body. She said: “She is with me every day in my heart but I will not have peace until I can bury Susan and visit her grave. “I just wish Grfiths would tell me or the police where she is. I don’t know why he won’t. “Perhaps he feels that he retains some power over us. And he does because I want to go and put flowers on Susan’s resting place and only he can grant me that wish.” Christine said her daughter, a former grammar school pupil, slid into the seedy world of drugs and vice after a brain haemorrhage that brought on epilepsy. “Susan was trying to turn her le around and was doing really well and was getting off the drugs and staying with me. “The day she went ­missing she said she was going out to get some medicine and would be back soon, but she never came home.”

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA mum-to-be in labour ended up giving birth in a garden centre with a pair of shoelaces used to tie her babyaposs umbilical cord. Emily Rumney, , was dashing to hospital with partner James Perry, , when she realised their baby couldnapost wait so they were forced to use Secret Garden in Pontypool, South Wales, as a makesht delivery suite. Baby Leah arrived shortly after at am weighing lb oz with James acting as midwe to deliver his own daughter - and tied her umbilical cord with his shoelaces. The proud dad said: It was about .am when Emily started having contractions. I rang the hospital and they said she should have two paracetamol, a hot bath, and go back to bed. At .am she had the two paracetamol and tried to go back to sleep. But by .am it was clear we had to head for the hospital, so we got everything together and set off. The couple were just a couple of miles into their -mile journey to hospital from their home in Sebastapol, near Pontypool, when the baby decided to enter the world. Emily - a clinical trials co-ordianator at a specialist cancer hospital - told James she could feel the head.  Factory manager James said: I pulled into the Secret Garden car park. It was am by now, and I could see that I would have to deliver her. James was trying to give information on their whereabouts to the  operator when Leah arrived. I put her on Emilyaposs chest and was then told I had take a lace out of one of my trainers and tie that around the umbilical cord, he said.  I got a towel to clean the baby, and blankets to cover her and Emily up to keep them warm, put the heater on, and waited for the ambulance. Emily couldnapost go into hospital until it was an active labour, but we didnapost expect things to go so quickly.

title: mum tells kids daddys heaven
story: NewsMum tells kids daddys in heaven as husband dies just two days after weddingGavin and Kirsty Howarth had to bring their wedding forward after the groom was given just two months to live following a shock cancer diagnosis and his condition deterioratedShareCommentsByElizabeth Rushton:,  MAY NewsGavin and Kirsty Howarth with three-year-old Lucian and seven-year-old Bryce " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A mum has been left heartbroken after her cancer-stricken husband died just two days after they got married.Kirsty Howarth, , said her youngest child only really understands that daddy’s in heaven now after her partner Gavin Howarth, , died in early May. Mr Howarth, from Rochdale, Greater Manchester, was given just two months to live on Easter Sunday in April after he was found to have a lymphoma and tumours in his liver, kidneys and brain.Mrs Howarth told the Manchester Evening News: I’ve been finding it quite hard but my kids have got me through. I have to keep going for them. to get the Mirroraposs biggest and best stories delivered straight to your inbox at www.mirror email. My eldest is up and down, sometimes he says he misses his daddy. The youngest doesn’t know too much of what’s going on but he just knows that daddy’s in heaven now. The Howarths had a three-year-old son, Lucian, and Mr Howarth was stepdad to his weaposs older son, Bryce, who is seven. After the shock diagnosis, Mr Howarthaposs condition took a turn for the worse on April  and the couple got married in their front room that evening. The dad died less than  hours later.  Mrs Howarthaposs mum, Sandra Whittaker, said: They were a really special couple. Gavin was a great man, smiling all the time - he had a heart of gold. He was a great dad, boyfriend and husband and a fantastic stepdad to Bryce - he knew his favourite superhero was Superman, so he went to pick him up from school one time all dressed up and took him to McDonaldaposs. That’s the kind of person he was. The pair had discussed tying the knot before the diagnosis. But they were waiting to make sure they had enough money for a dream wedding. Mr Howarth was diagnosed after he suffered shortness of breath and severe back pain for weeks. It was thought that his symptoms were due to asthma and lting involved in his work as a carpet fitter. The pain became so bad that he left his job and started working at a fish and chip shop last October.  He saw a GP in March and he underwent tests to determine whether he had tuberculosis, a bacterial infection he had as a child and resulted in one of his lungs being removed. Doctors discovered a lymphoma and tumours in his liver, kidneys and brain. After being given the terminal diagnosis, the couple decided to get married on May  in the garden of their home in Kirkholt. However, the pair had to get married inside their home due to Mr Howarthaposs worsening condition. Friends, neighbours and businesses had donated items for an outdoor ceremony and reception.  Ms Whittaker said: I had a group of about  or  friends who I thought could help and asked them to spread the word. We were just overwhelmed by what people gave us - some gave us some white drapes or some articial flowers to make the place look beautul, people offered us a balloon arch and some pretty white fairy lights. “My brother-in-law, James Oldham, spent three days doing up the garden, cleaning up all the stone work, planting flowers and making it nice for them. Even though it didn’t end up happening in the garden, we still had people offering to come and do hair and make up and other nice things.” One Shop Weddings donated £, worth of wedding supplies and Morrisons gave party food for the reception.  Ms Whittaker added: Some people have donated money, people they don’t even know. I had no idea people could be so lovely - we only asked for a few items but to think of what we got, I just can’t say thank you enough. Mrs Howarth was told to bring the wedding forward after a visit from nurses.Two registrars came to their home that evening despite the coronavirus lockdown and the couple was married at pm with their two boys, Ms Whittaker, Mr Howarthaposs mum Mandy present.Mr Howarthaposs brother Lee and sister Gina, and Mrs Howarthaposs dad Karl watched from the garden.

title: nurse who couldnt feel feet
story: NewsNurse who couldnt feel feet after -hour sht walks home in tears after bike stolenLily Richardson, , had just finished a long sht on the frontline when she discovered her £ bike she had only bought three days ago was stolen, leaving her in tearsShareCommentsByKatie DickinsonJamie Hawkins:,  MAY NewsLily Richardson finished a gruelling -hour sht to find her bicycle had been stolen " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA frontline student nurse helping with the coronavirus battle walked home in tears after her bike was stolen outside the hospital. Lily Richardson, , had just finished a gruelling -hour sht at Newcastle’s Royal Victoria Infirmary when she noticed her £ bicycle, which she only had for three days, was gone. She was told by a security guard that her bike had been stolen, meaning she has had to walk to and from work ever since. Lily, who lives in Boldon, is now appealing for help in tracing her bright orange Cube bicycle.The third year student nurse arrived for her sht at the RVI at .am on Monday, May , ChronicleLive reports.“I locked it right outside the hospital,” she said. “As well as spending a fortune on the bike I spent an extra £ to get a good lock.” But she emerged from the hospital at .pm, it was nowhere to be found. Lily said: “I’m doing the job I love, but I’d had a long sht, I couldn’t feel my feet. I walked outside and my bike just wasn’t there. “At first it didn’t really sink in, until a security guard said, ‘I’m sorry pet, your bike’s been stolen’. “I didn’t really think someone would take my bike from outside work, it’s mindboggling that someone would do that, especially in the current situation.” Lily was later told that a man wearing a hoodie and with his face covered had been seen standing outside the hospital at around .pm. She said: “He was there for ages. Police were doing patrols and they saw this suspicious guy and approached him “Apparently when they approached him he put what looked like wire snippers in his bag and took off. “There were lots of cars trying to chase him but he went down the university and cars can’t go down there. “The police did try and chase him, two officers rang to say they were sorry they didn’t catch him. “I just had to walk home and cry, and I’m still walking in. It’s a nightmare. Lily is now appealing for anyone who sees the bike, or sees it being sold, to get in touch with the police. She said: “It wasn’t so much the bike, it’s the principle of it. They would have known it was an NHS worker’s bike. It’s just beyond me why they would do that. “I’m still hoping I might get it back. My mum says I’m being optimistic, but I am quite an optimistic person.” Northumbria Police’s Neighbourhood Inspector for Newcastle city centre, Karen Madge, said: “At .pm on Monday we received a report that a bicycle had been stolen from the site of the RVI in Newcastle. Officers attended the area but the suspect had already fled the scene, it later emerged that the bicycle belonged to a nurse at the hospital. We are carrying out extensive enquiries to identy the bicycle and locate the offender. That includes the review of CCTV cameras in the area and high visible patrols around the area of the hospital.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA pub boss says he has managed to find a safe way for customers to enjoy a tipple while social distancing. Drinkers at the The Betsey Wynne in Swanbourne, Buckinghamshire, will enter and leave through a one-way system and be seated at tables two metres apart that are separated by Perspex screens. Customers will be urged to keep their hands clean with gel dispensers visually displayed throughout the premises and they will use disposable menus to place their order using a phone app. The pub would have a limit of  customers but the premises is spacious and also has a big beer garden. Peter Borg-Neal, CEO of Oakman Inns which owns the pub said is being used as a prototype to demonstrate how the scheme could offer pubs a leline. He told The Sun: “The country is desperate for a proper pint in the pub and we are asking the Government to treat us like grown-ups and let us open. “We strongly believe in this idea and are presenting it to the Cabinet Office via our trade body, UK Hospitality. A government adviser is reportedly supportive of the measures and brewery chiefs say it can be in place three weeks after getting the green light. The innovative plan comes hospitality bosses have warned that around , pubs may have to close their doors permanentlythey are among the last businesses to be allowed to reopen by the government. Boris Johnson previously announced the hospitality sector - including pubs and bars - must remain closed until at least July. The British Beer  Pub Associationhas warned that up  per cent of Britainaposs pubs cannot survive beyond September with the current level of financial support being offered by the Government. Emma McClarkin, chief executive of the BBPA, said despite looking for a glimmer of hope, the industry now faced further weeks of uncertainty. With insufficient clarity as to when pubs will reopen, our sector remains in limbo and facing severe uncertainty and financial devastation, she said. Mr Borg-Neal echoed her claims adding that pubs need to reopen to get the economy aposgoing againapos.  He said when the lockdown was announced  barrelsfrom The Betsey had to be ed to the brewery. He added: “I can get on a Tube train with a load of strangers but I can’t go and have a pint in the pub with a mate. Where is the logic ” Government adviser Professor Robert Dingwall said: “If it is a sunny weekend and the pub has a garden and the landlords are prepared to accept responsibility for not overcrowding it, I see no particular reason why it should not reopen.” Mr Borg-Neal added: “We’d need three weeks’ notice to get in deliveries so evenwe got the all-clear on Monday we wouldn’t open until next month.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailReal ale nut Richard Percival has something brewing in his spare room – Britain’s biggest beer tray collection. The retired business consultant has masses of round ones. But there are also square ones, oval ones and expensive ones picked up on his travels. The designs tell a story of beer-making through the decades. Some rare finds are from as far afield as the US, New Zealand and Australia. Richard, , has spent almost  years hoarding more than , of the pub mementos. And he has no plans to call “time please, gents” on his unusual interest. He says: “At first my family thought I was stark raving mad and were embarrassed when I used to ask publicans for spare trays. “I’d start with the words ‘I have an unusual hobby’. You could feel them cringe. But my collection is British history and that’s why people want to see it. “It is unique. Many of the breweries no longer exist.” Richard got hooked while on a footie trip with a beer mat-collecting pal back in .  He recalls: “I didn’t pay anything for my first tray. I’m a Notts County supporter and in  I was on an away trip to Brighton. “A fellow fan collected beer mats and asked a landlord for a specic mat. “The landlord only had a tray so I took it and that’s where it all started.”  It took we Susan, a -year-old retired solicitor, time to accept his unusual interest. Richard adds: “These days my family accepts my passion is preserving brewery history and my we even encouraged a few items to be displayed in the kitchen. Susan does appreciate it represents brewing history. “She’s happy about my display room and lets me have items in my office. But beyond that I’m banned from discussing it.”  Son Tim, , is on board too and Richard says: “He thinks I’m nuts but he always keeps an eye out for me when he’s out drinking”. Richard has two pints of ale most nights and loves Fullers ESB, Bathams and Elgood’s Black Dog Mild. He’ll open a fresh cask when pals visit. “My friends continue to take the mickey but deep down they’re impressed,” he says.  Richard, from Rutland, spends up to £ a time on trays, many sourced from the internet. But, just like his first, landlords often give them away. His oldest example, a small oval copper item from the Lyde Green Brewery in Cradley, West Mids, dates from the s. And his favourite is an oval tray from Warwicks  Richardsons brewery in Newark, Notts.

The home may look teeny from the outside but step inside the front door and this unassuming home in Bridgnorth, Shropshire, hides an incredible secret. The cottage was the home of artist Antony Dracup, who spent years transforming it from a traditional terrace into something far more interesting. It boasts two bedrooms, a living room and a galley kitchen, perfect for family cooking. But walk further into the home and youaposll come to a massive sandstone cave, which comes complete with vaulted celings, ornate pillars and tile mosaics. And Antony didnapost stop there, he also created stunning landscaped gardens, a roof terrace, an attic room and a bathroom. Not only that but the determined artist completed many of his cave excavations by hand. His son, Dennis, explained: Every house that he took up residence in received the Dracup treatment – arches, pillars, balustrades, moulding, marbling, graining, nishing, stained-glass all designed and crafted from start to finish by his hand. In true Colditz style – a little every day, but persistently – he chiselled away. His persistence was rewarded with noticeably stronger chest muscles and extra living space.Antony died in  when he was  but he used the sandstone caves that are common in the area he lived in in Shropshire for his inspiration for the incredible adjustments to his home. The caves had previously been used as a place for young people to socialise but now form part of this unusual home. After moving into the home in the s, Antony worked tirelessly to transform it. The huge cave structure now makes up half the size of the property and he also levelled parts of the home to create ever bigger living spaces.But his first job was to sound-proof his house using an extra layer of bricks before he set about chiseling away at the cave that was originally in part of the garden. His son says on a website dedicated to his fatheraposs work: By way of a ladder it was possible to access the four levels of terracing, oddly and asymmetrically designed so as to fully involve the climber in the experience -you darenapost put a foot wrong here. Cast concrete, decorative features and moulding shared the daylight with lettuce, tomatoes an apple tree and much other edible produce. A vertical kitchen-garden which, to my fatheraposs delight, was once mistaken for a Roman Ruin in a local aerial survey.  Following Antonyaposs death all the subsequent owners have stayed true to his vision, keeping his stunning cave and all the intricate touches he had added. The -year-old was found by a patrol officer in Missouri in the middle of the night walking in traffic. His face, legs, and arms were covered with bruises, according to the officer, who said the child had a packed bag with him. The boyaposs parents, Christopher Crets, , and -year-old step-mother Nicole Crets, were arrested the next day with felony child abuse. Mr Crets was also charged with kidnapping along with four counts of unlawful possession of a firearm. Warren County Sherf Kevin Harrison said it was a aposmiracleapos the child wasnapost seriously injured.He told KSDK: It’s just a miracle that this boy wasn’t seriously injured. Brian Hitchens previously said he didnapost think Covid- was real, and stated that God is bigger than this virus will ever be. Brian took to Facebook in April to play down any concerns about the virus, which has so far killed almost , people in the US. “Iaposd get up in the morning and pray and trust in God for his protection, and I’d just leave it at that. Under Operation Warp Speed, the US government will invest in leading vaccine candidates and get ready to distribute them on a mass scale, the President announced yesterday. A crack team drawing from the government, military and pharmaceutical industry will work with other countries to find a jab that can prevent Covid-, widely seen as the only long-term way to bring the global pandemic under control.
