to the payments, although the amount workers take home will not fall below the  per cent mark.How much will businesses be expected to pay towards furlough The details will be published later this month, the Chancellor said, but it is likely to be judged on a sector-by-sector basis, similar to the details published on Monday by the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategyfor companies looking to reopen under new ldquoCovid Secure measures.With certain sectors ing to some normality, others, including restaurants and gyms, remain unlikely to reopen fully for several months.Can we expect to see furlough extended beyond October The Government has said it will continue to monitor the situation and is willing to adjust advice accordingly.But Mr Sunak made clear it is unlikely to be extended.He told the Commons: ldquoWe will keep everything under review but my expectation is by thenthe scheme should end. Wersquove stretched and strained to be as generous as possible to businesses and workers, which is why we have made the decision that wersquove made today.The Chancellor added: ldquoBut hellip this scheme is expensive. Itrsquos the right thing to do. The cost of not acting would have been far higher but itrsquos not something that can continue indefinitely into the future. Eight months of total support is a considerable amount of time.Are there any other signicant changes to the furlough scheme More details will come this month, but MPs raised concerns from self-employed workers who pay themselves via idends, asking whether they would be able to receive further support.However, Mr Sunak insisted current support is strong enough.Why is the Government announcing the extension now Under employment laws, companies must start informing any staff they plan to make redundant within  days of any changes.The previous furlough scheme was due to end by July, meaning consultations would need to begin imminently, but the extension to October will address it.

title: borders-actor-jack-lowden-narrates-bbc-football-documentary
story: BORDERS actor Jack Lowden contributed to a BBC documentary aired across Scotland last night .The former Earlston High School pupil narrated Return to Real Kashmir FCabout a Scottish football managers job in Asia.The BBC Scotland show was a sequel to an earlier programme documenting Davie Robertsons first season in charge.Lowden, , narrated the story of Robertsonsto the disputed Himalayan region.In Robertsons playing career, he racked up more than  appearances for both Aberdeen and Rangers, following up with spells at Leeds United and Montrose.

title: let-borders-garden-centres-open-soon-says-msp
story: BORDERS residents should be allowed to visit garden centres soon, according to a politician.Christine Grahame MSP has asked the Scottish Government to consider re-opening such businesses with safety measures in place.Ms Grahame, of the SNP, highlighted the "physical and mental wellbeing benefits" of gardening.The member for Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale addressed Holyroods rural economy and connectivity committee this morning.She said: ldquoAny re-opening of businesses of course needs to be done in a safe manner, giving proper consideration to the safety of both staff and the public."Irsquom optimistic that this may be possible with garden centres soon, given the physical and mental wellbeing benefits gardening can offer for us all in lockdown.ldquoIf yoursquore fortunate enough to have access to a garden it can make a real dference and being able to buy some supplies for it could be a real boost to many. Indeed even a window box can make a dference. While you can currently buy online, it is not as satisfactory.ldquoOur horticultural sector has been hit hard by lockdown, with many businesses losing out on what would be one of their busiest periods of trade in spring and early summer."This not only affects the big well known chains, but smaller local businesses and growers.ldquoI welcome news that this is being given serious consideration and I trust the Scottish Government will authorise re-opening soon."

title: john-lamont-cancels-summer-tour-first-time-14-years
story: A BORDERS politician has announced he is cancelling his summer surgery tour for the first time in more than a decade.John Lamont MP and Rachael Hamilton MSP, both Conservatives, had been due to visit  towns and villages over the summer.But with coronavirus restrictions in place, the pair are scrapping their plans.Mr Lamont, who formerly held Ms Hamiltons Holyrood seat, expressed sadness that he would be missing an annual "highlight" for himself.He said: "Irsquom really disappointed that for the first time in  years, it will not be happening this summer."The member for Berwickshire, Roxburgh and Selkirk ndash who won his first parliamentary election in  ndash said it is important to follow government advice aimed at limiting the spread of COVID-.He added that he continues to hold surgeries over the phone.Ms Hamilton, who represents Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire in the Scottish Parliament, said she is also "disappointed" about the tour cancellation.She added: "I am very much looking forward to meeting constituents again in hopefully the near future when the restrictions are safely lted."

title: borders-businessman-making-living-unwanted-trees
story: AN ENTREPRENEUR is enjoying success by helping to make houses, animal shavings and food pallets.Douglas Mathison, , of Peeblesshire, fells trees across the south of Scotland through his company Agrorest.ldquoEven with the poorest quality timber, you can still get a lot of use out of it, says Mr Mathison, explaining that unwanted woods on farms and estates have the potential to serve a iety of purposes.Once the timber has been taken to the sawmill, Mr Mathison says, the best of it gets transformed into timber-framed houses, while the scraps might ultimately line a rabbit hutch.When Agrorest was founded in , it served a role that was ldquounique in the south of Scotland, according to Mr Mathison.Established firms often shunned the type of tasks that Agrorest expressed an interest in, he says.ldquoWhen I first started, we were the only one in the south of Scotland that was doing this work on a very small basis, Mr Mathison says.ldquoWersquove been taking on an increasing workload, focusing on smaller jobs that other companies are not interested in working on.Although there are now three or four other firms carrying out a similar role in the region, according to Mr Mathison, Agrorest continues to field enquiries from Kilmarnock to West Linton and beyond.Explaining the typical process, Mr Mathison says an initial phone call will often lead to a site visit, which in turn results in Mr Mathison estimating the potential financialthat could be made on a patch of woodlandfelled.If the farmer wishes to press ahead and Mr Mathison secures a licence from Scottish Forestry, Agrorest will send in the machinery, remove the trees and take the timber to sawmills.The farmer can be paid within a few weeks, according to Mr Mathison, who shares a portion of the money he receives from the mills.Aside from felling, Agrorest carries out replanting and also manages a number of estates.Mr Mathison says his success has overcome a historical perception among certain landowners that woodland is ldquonot worth bothering about.In his experience, he says, an undermanaged patch of trees will be worthy of attention ldquonine times out of .Mr Mathison is a former Peebles High School pupil who went on to study rural business management in Edinburgh.He launched Agrorest after a stint working for a large timber harvesting company.

title: 22m-coronavirus-support-approved-borders-businesses
story: MORE than pound million in coronavirus support has been approved for Borders businesses.Scottish Borders Councilhas been managing a portion of the Scottish Governmentrsquos Business Support Fund.More than , payments have now been processed, according to the local authority, amounting to a total of pound. million.Two forms of one-off help are available ndash a pound, grant and a pound, grant, with dfering eligibility criteria.Application forms can be accessed here.

title: 2-000-payments-approved-self-employed-people-borders
story: SELF-EMPLOYED people in the Borders have started receiving money from the council in the form of coronavirus support.The Newly Self-Employed Hardship Fund was launched on May .Since then,  people have been approved for a one-off payment of pound,, according to Scottish Borders Council.The money has been made available by the Scottish Government, with people eligible to applythey set up in business on or after April , .

title: golfers-raise-10-000-peebles-golf-club
story: GOLFERS have donated more than pound, to help Peebles Golf Club while the course is closed.The clubs fundraising drive, launched after the coronavirus lockdown, collected more than pound, last month.Les Biscomb, of the clubs sponsorship sub-committee, hailed the generosity of donors.Reflecting on the campaign so far, he said: ldquoItrsquos been a tremendous success."Unlike golf clubs south of the border, Scottish courses remain closed ndash meaning clubhouse coffers continue to struggle.But the idea of setting up a fundraiser in Peebles has already been vindicated, according to Mr Biscomb.He said: "As a team, we came up with the idea of, while wersquore in lockdown, our members might have vastly reduced income ndash theyrsquore being paid to work at home or are pensioners ndash but therersquos nowhere to spend your money at the moment."You canrsquot go to golf, you canrsquot go down the pub, you canrsquot go to restaurants, many people arenrsquot driving anywhere, so we thought, while wersquore in lockdown, why donrsquot we ask the members in Peebles, who are kindhearted and generous, to put something each month towards a crowdfunder.Comments by donors on the website include, Have my coffee money for the coming month otherwise Irsquoll probably fritter it away and Glad to donate again to ensure our club survives.The sub-committee originally set a target of pound, each month, but received more than pound, in April.Mr Biscomb said: ldquoWe would have been delightedwersquod raised the pound, but in the very first month alone we got to pound,."Some of those were one-offs, so people just wanted to join in with the giving and the spirit of helping the club but even so,you look at May, wersquore already at pound,.ldquoWe were hoping for this to continue for two or three months, pound, a month, just to add in the coffers."This isnrsquot funding thatrsquos needed immediately ndash from a cash perspective, Peebles is doing well."This is really for the quiet periods. Once we turn the corner into next year, thatrsquos really when we might need this money, in the quieter days.ldquoBut who knows whatrsquos going to happen with lockdown, and when wersquore going to get cash back through other means, like the bar and catering, and visitors.Currently, all club staff are on furlough, with the exception of head greenkeeper Steve Borthwick.ldquoSteversquos going a fantastic job, said Mr Biscomb. "The course is in magnicent condition ndash it is very tempting to get out there.Meanwhile, British Prime Minister Boris Johnson has announced that golf clubs in England can re-open, as long as social distancing guidelines are followed.Mr Biscomb conceded he is "quite jealous", but indicated he is satisfied with the Scottish rules.He said: ldquoIrsquod love to get out on the golf course. But equally, we understand that the Scottish Government is not ready because the stats are not there."Theyrsquore not comfortable with opening golf clubs and we have to respect that."Hopefully, in a few weeksrsquo time,the number [of virus cases] comes down, we can start to get out in ones and twos."For now, we have to live with it and be sensible."Wersquore in the eighth week already ndash another couple of weeks wonrsquot do any harm."Itrsquos achievable to be sensible for another few weeks.Donations to Peebles Golf Club can be made via: www.justgiving crowdfunding pgcmembersappealfund

title: mountain-bikers-told-ride-within-limits-lockdown
story: MOUNTAIN bikers have been issued with guidance during lockdown.Scottish Cyclinghas outlined a series of dos and donts following the Scottish Governments go-ahead for people to exercise more than once a day.There are four rules cyclists and mountain bikers must adhere to under the new SC guidelines:Only ride from your home ndash it is not essential travel to go mountain biking or cycling and you may face enquiries from the policeyou are stopped en route or ing from a ride. All Forestry and Land Scotland car parks and trails, including the stanes sites, remain closedDo not go far ndash whilst you can go exercise for longer, we recommend riding close to where you live and not into remote areas ndash think more smaller loops rather than one longer remote rideRide well within your limits ndash only ride on trails that are that you are very confident you will be able to ride safely and within your competency. It is highly unlikely that mountain rescue are back to full operations ndash consider the fact that a full rescue may not be possible and may take longer to get to youOnly cycle with members of your own household - keep a safe distance when passing other cyclists or pedestrians.Mountain biking trails such as the stanes at Glentress, Peebles, and Innerleithen are closed until further notice to restrict travel to the trails and for safety as they are not being maintained as they were before lockdown.However, walking trails owned by Forestry and Land Scotland are open to members of the public who can access them without using transport.

title: subway-store-galashiels-busy-since-re-opening
story: SUBWAY in Galashiels has re-opened for takeaway and delivery.The sandwich store, which had closed due to coronavirus restrictions, welcomed customers back this week.The Channel Street premises opened its doors again on Monday , applying social distancing guidance and using protective gear.Store supervisor Imran Han said the shop has been "busy".

title: borders-lib-dems-select-ettrick-roxburgh-berwickshire-candidate
story: THE Liberal Democrats have selected a candidate for next years Holyrood election.Jenny Marr will stand for the Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire constituency ndash currently held by Conservative Rachael Hamilton.The former Selkirk High pupil said: "Irsquom thrilled to have been chosen to represent Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire for the Scottish Liberal Democrats."We are living in extraordinary times and I have been blown away by how communities across the Borders have rallied to support each other."The most important thing we can do as politicians and political parties is to provide assistance to anyone that needs it, learn from our experiences and work to address inequalities which have manest."The vote is set to take place on Thursday, May  of next year.

title: borders-based-msp-introduces-online-advice-surgeries
story: A BORDERS-BASED MSP is introducing video surgeries for his constituents.Paul Wheelhouse, who represents the South of Scotland, has had to temporarily close his Hawick office due to the coronavirus outbreak.But from next Friday, Borderers will be able to have a face-to-face meeting ndash without leaving their homes.Mr Wheelhouse said: "Video advice surgeries will be secure and confidential. Constituents will be able to talk to me as though we were sitting down together in person."I fully appreciate that many people do not have video-conferencing technology, or do not even have the internet in their home. For those people, my office is still contactable by telephone at this time."The online advice surgeries are to complement, not replace, other forms of communication. I would strongly encourage anyone who needs my support to get in touch, either by email or phone, and myself and my team will assist in any way we can."Mr Wheelhousersquos first online surgery will take place from pm on Friday, May .To make an appointment, email: paul.wheelhouse.msp@parliament.scot

title: 75-students-without-laptop-get-device-borders-college
story: BORDERS College has loaned laptops to  students who did not have regular access to a suitable device at home.With face-to-face classes cancelled due to coronavirus restrictions, learning has been taking place remotely.Student who did not have adequate laptops of their own have been allowed to borrow from the Galashiels campus.Sport and exercise student Harrison Dixon, from Earlston, said he was "delighted" with the scheme.He said: ldquoMy personal computer is old and struggling to work with some of the new applications and online resources that we are now using, so I spoke with my course tutor who made me aware of the loan scheme, and I was delighted when it was delivered last week."Having the laptop will allow me to continue with my studies remotely.The college says it has loaned a total of  laptops, including those allocated through its bursary programme.Head of IT Scott Moncrieff said: ldquoBefore the college closed, we were able to prepare and distribute  laptops to students for use."Since lockdown, we have had an additional  requests, which we have been able to fulfil.ldquoAny students who find themselves in the situation that continuing their education is not possible, because they donrsquot have an appropriate device, should contact their course tutor or achievement coach, and they will make the appropriate arrangements.

title: historic-borders-houses-feature-visitscotland-campaign
story: HISTORIC homes in the Borders are featuring in a social media campaign by VisitScotland.The tourist organisation has launched #AWindowOnScotland, which asks people to take a photo from their window.Traquair House, Peeblesshire, is among the stately homes in the Borders taking part, with views from the th century Aikwood Tower, near Selkirk, also being shared across social media.Gillian Steele, chairwoman of Big Houses in the Scottish Borders, said: "I donrsquot think people will necessarily forget we are here, but with us all looking out of our windows dreaming of that day when we can travel again, and indulge our passion for Scottish heritage, this campaign strikes a chord."VisitScotlandrsquos #AWindowOnScotland campaign provides us with a great visual opportunity to continue to promote our Houses, their gardens and their wildle from the same perspective as everyone at home."Irsquom encouraging all the Big Houses to take part, and I hope between the eleven of us we will give visitors a reminder of how beautul our Houses and gardens look this month."The campaigns hashtag has been used , times, with towns and villages across the Borders taking part.Historic buildings participating include Thirlestane Castle, near Lauder, and Mellerstain House, near Kelso.VisitScotlands regional leadership director Paula Ward said: ldquoWersquore thrilled at the reaction to #AWindowOnScotland from residents across the Scottish Borders and heartened that businesses are engaging with the campaign and using the opportunity to share their windows on Scotland with the world during this challenging time.ldquoThe staycation market will be a key driver in the countryrsquos economic recovery and the many wonderful views people have been sharing while they stay at home will surely be an incentive for many to travel when the time comes.ldquoThe campaign is far from over and wersquod encourage residents and businesses to continue posting their views, however they may look, as it is all Scotland, to help lt the spirits of those at home and abroad.To join the campaign, take a photo of a view from your window and share it online using #AWindowOnScotland, then tag your location.

title: national-express-plans-resume-coach-services-july-1
story: National Express has started selling UK coach tickets as it plans to restart services on July .The tickets will be available for a "core coach network" andwill focus on large and medium-sized towns and cities.Revenue dropped about  per cent in April compared withthe same month last year, National Express revealed, as the Government advised Britons to keep away from public transport.Nevertheless, Ebitdawas positive and slightly ahead of expectations as National Express slashed costs by about pound million.What hasNational Express said In a statement to customers, National Express said: "We have extended the temporary suspension of our coach services."A restricted timetable is currently scheduled to resume from Wednesday, July , ."Please note, however, all services are subject to change depending on Government advice."For thosethat have an upcoming journey booked with us on or before June ,  and would like to amend your booking, you can do so for free, for travel any time in the next  months."There is no need to contact us straight away, just completeour ticket amendment formbefore your original outward journey and get back in touch with us when yoursquore ready to travel again."If you do not wish to amend your ticket to another date, we will provide a full refund. If you havenrsquot already done so, please completeour refund formand we will process your refund within  days."Please stay safe and well and, when the time is right, we look forward to welcoming you back on board."Where does National Express travel to The company runs coach services across the UK, including Manchester to Coventry, London to Worthing, Newcastle via Darlington to London, Liverpool to Leeds, Edinburgh and Glasgow to London, plus Bradford to London.

title: graphic-designer-reveals-inspired-borders-kids
story: A GRAPHIC designer is helping to keep families entertained during lockdown after creating free colouring packs.Kate Pearson, , who owns K Graphic Design, has created six art packs to help ease the boredom of being stuck indoors.Kate, of Peebles, said: "I absolutely love my job because I get to be creative every day."Each pack features dferent activities for children ndash and adults ndash including colouring, design, and games like word searches.Kate said: "Just before lockdown, I spoke to the pupils at my old primary school, Priorsford Primary School, about my career."I left feeling inspired by their enthusiasm and the idea of activity packs was born."She had planned to print the packs but wanted them to be accessible so made them digital ndash a decision which has paid off.The downloads page on her website has been visited more than , times in the last two months, she said.Kate ensured that each pack had something for everyone, with themes including rainbows and dinosaurs."They were designed with young people in mind, but have proved to be just as popular with adults ndash especially the dinosaur one," said Kate.Kate also owns Glass Bulldog Wedding Stationary, and with wedding fairs for  cancelled or postponed, both sides of her business have taken a knock."Ninety per cent of my bookings have been cancelled or postponed until next year ndash many of my suppliers are affected too," said Kate."I really feel for all businesses facing closure and couples postponing their weddings."Like everyone, the biggest challenge of COVID- is not seeing friends and family, but staying at home is such a small price to pay to stay safe ndash especially now lsquoNeighboursrsquo is back on five days a week!"Kate ed to Peebles only a few years ago, after enjoying multiple career roles including as a wedding planner and working for a London-based design agency.Looking to the future, Kate already has three new packs in mind and hopes to eventually print the activity books.She also hopes that once the Borders s to normal, many of her usual services will be back up and running, especially those catered for weddings and events."My clients range from small local start-ups to The Botanic Gardens and Amazon ndash no two days are the same," she said."Going freelance also means I can take my dog, Dr Frankenstein, to work. What more could you ask for "

title: tesco-clubcard-vouchers-set-expire-extended-november-2020
story: A BATCH of Tesco Clubcard vouchershave been extended by the supermarket.The extension comes as Tesco says customers across the UK have not been shopping as frequently as before the lockdown period began in March.Herersquos everything you need to know.Changing shopping habitsWith some customers unable to visit stores at all during lockdown, and others visiting less frequently, shopping habits have changed over the past few months.Tesco has reported that visits to the supermarket have halved since lockdown, but basket sizes have doubled.Clubcard vouchers extendedHowever, those with Clubcard vouchers could now be struggling to spend them before they expire,they cannot get to a store or book a delivery slot.Tesco has therefore issued a statement to shoppers stating that Clubcard points that were due to expire this month will now be extended, Manchester Evening News reports.Zoe Evans, of Tescos customer engagement centre, said:"We appreciate that, for many reasons, most of us arenrsquot shopping as often as we did before lockdown."As a little help from Clubcard, we want to give you more time to use your vouchers which were due to expire on May , ."Any vouchers issued in May  will now not expire until November , , giving you an extra six months to use them."Well update the expiry date on your digital vouchers, and well continue to accept paper vouchers in-store until the extended expiry date. We really hope it helps, and take care."

title: opposition-mps-write-eu-negotiator-seek-brexit-talks-extension
story: Europersquos chief Brexit negotiator has been told there is ldquosignicant opposition to the UK Governmentrsquos refusal to consider extending the timetable for talks.Both the SNP leader at Westminster Ian Blackford and the acting Liberal Democrat leader Sir Ed Davey have signed a letter to Michel Barnier, supporting an extension to the transition period.Such a move would allow talks to place when ldquothe efforts of national governments and the European Union will not be engaged solely with dealing with the dreadful Covid- epidemic, they said.vw,vw,px, px"SNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford. With the UK having formally quit the European Union, talks are taking place between the UK and EU to determine key areas such as future trading relationships.But with the transition period due to expire at the end of this year, there are fears the UK may be forced into a no-deal scenario,an agreement cannot be reached.The letter to Mr Barnier has also been signed byPlaid Cymru MP Liz Saville Roberts, Green MP Caroline Lucas, Stephen Farry, MP from the Alliance Party, as well as fellow Northern Ireland MP Colum Eastwood of the Social Democratic and Labour Party.They contacted Mr Barnier to highlight the ldquosignicant opposition to the UK Governmentrsquos extreme position amongst the business community, the general public and elected representatives.The opposition MPs noted the Scottish and Welsh governments both backed an extension of the transition period, along with ldquothe majority of political parties in the Northern Ireland Executive.vw,vw,px, px"Sir Ed Davey , acting leader of the Liberal Democrats. The MPs said: ldquoA consensus is taking shape and we hope the UK Government will soon recognise reality.ldquoIt is now in all of our common interests to agree and secure an extension to the transition period. This will enable these detailed and defining negotiations to be conducted at a time when, we hope, the efforts of national governments and the European Union will not be engaged solely with dealing with the dreadful Covid- epidemic.SNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford said they had written to Mr Barnier because ldquotime is running out until we hit the hard Brexit deadline.He insisted: ldquoIt is vital that the Tory government does the only responsible thing and accepts a two-year extension to the transition period.The SNP MP continued: ldquoCrashing out with a bad deal or no deal in the middle of the coronavirus crisis, would deal a double hammer blow to the economy just when we will need all the help we can get to save jobs, businesses and living standards.But he claimed: ldquoIt increasingly appears the Tory government is intent on taking Scotland and the UK down the path of a devastating no-deal. That would be beyond reckless.ldquoThe coronavirus economic crash is the worst in living memory. People and businesses are already struggling to getby. The Tory government must put its responsibilities to the economy ahead of its Brexit obsession.ldquoPolls consistently show that the overwhelming majority of people in Scotland and across the UK want to see an extension to the Brexit transition period ndash and there is growing consensus across political parties. Itrsquos time for the UK Government to act.A UK Government spokesman said: ldquoThe Government was elected on a manesto which made clear the transition period would end on December , . That isenshrined in primary legislation and it remains our policy.ldquoWe will not ask to extend the transition period, andthe EU asks we will say no.ldquoExtending the transition period would simply increase uncertainty and prolong the negotiations, whilst also leaving us bound by EU legislation and obliged to make further payments into the EU budget..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Opposition MPs write to EU negotiator to seek Brexit talks extension

title: hs2-bosses-accused-blindsided-contact-reality
story: HS bosses have been ldquoblindsided by contact with reality with the project ldquobadly off course, according to MPs.In a report published by Westminsterrsquos Public Accounts Committee , fresh concerns have been raised by MPs over both the transparency and handling of the project.The Government has now been urged to give ldquoregular, accurate and open updates on problems faced by the project.Among its conclusions, the Committee said that the Department for Transportand HS Ltdrsquos lack of transparency had ldquoundermined public confidence in the programme.It also stated that the appearance of DfT Permanent Secretary Bernadette Kelly and HS Ltd executives, CEO Mark Thurston and chief financial officer Michael Bradley, before the Committee in March also ldquoraised questions about the previous picture provided by the witnesses of the projectrsquos health.The report read: ldquoThe Department and HS Ltd were aware of the scale of the issues facing the programme as early as October .ldquoIn March , HS Ltd formally notied the Department that it could not deliver Phase One to budget and schedule.ldquoDespite being aware of these issues, the Permanent Secretary withheld from us that the programme was in signicant dficulty when she appeared before the previous Committee in October  and May , even in response to specic questions about the programmersquos delivery timeline and budget.ldquoHS Ltdrsquos annual report and accounts for the year ending March   similarly failed to give an accurate account of the programmersquos problems.ldquoThe Department and HS Ltd defended their actions, stating that there were commercial sensitivities, and that options were still being pursued to remedy the situation.It added: ldquoWhile we recognise that ministers had not yet decided how to proceed, no adequate excuse was provided for not disclosing to this Committee and Parliament the risk and uncertainty the programme was facing.ldquoWe are disappointed by the Permanent Secretaryrsquos response to our concerns about her failure to explicitly inform the Committee of the programmersquos delays and overspend when asked about the general health of the project.Committee chair, Labour MP Meg Hillier, accused the Government of having made a ldquowealth of mistakes over major transport infrastructure.She said: ldquoThere is no excuse for hiding the nature and extent of the problems the project was facing from Parliament and the taxpayer.ldquoThe Department and HS appear to have been blindsided by contact with reality ndash when Phase One started moving through Parliament, the predicted costs of necessary commitments to the communities affected have exploded from pound million to pound. billion.ldquoThe Government unfortunately has a wealth of mistakes on major transport infrastructure to learn from, but it does not give confidence that it is finally going to take those lessons when this is its approach.She added: ldquoIn the six-monthly reports the Department has now agreed to give us, we want to see an honest, open account, and evidence of learning from past mistakes being applied to bring this project under control, to deliver it within the timeline and budget that have been agreed in justying the project.The Committeersquos deputy chair, Conservative MP Sir Geoffrey Clton-Brown, said that the PAC was ldquoin the dark about serious cost overruns.He said: ldquoThis PAC report on HS is one of the most critical, in both the transparency of Government and the handling of a project, that I have seen in my nine years in total on the committee.ldquoThe Permanent Secretary appeared before the committee in October  and again in May . In March , HS Ltd formally told the Department it had breached the terms of the Development Agreement, and would be unable to deliver the programme to cost and schedule ndash yet the Permanent Secretary did not inform the committee on either appearance that the programme was in trouble.ldquoThis is a serious breach of the departmentrsquos duty to Parliament and hence to the public, which as the report says, will undermine confidence. Furthermore, the PAC was in the dark about serious cost overruns and was therefore unable to do its duty to inform Parliament that value for money on the project was at risk.ldquoThe cost overruns have been blamed partly on the speed that the hybrid Bill committee for Phase One proceeded with. I was a member of that committee, which lasted for  months: this is complete nonsense.Responding to the report, a DfT spokesperson said: ldquoThe current Secretary of State has been clear that this project must go forward with a new approach to Parliamentary reporting, with clear transparency, strengthened accountability to ministers, and tight control of costs.ldquoWe have comprehensively reset the HS programme, introducing a revised budget and funding regime, with signicant reforms to ensure the project is delivered in a more disciplined and transparent manner.ldquoThis includes appointing the first dedicated HS minister, bi-annual updates to Parliament and establishing a monthly ministerial task force, chaired by the Secretary of State, to ensure the project has a rigorous scrutiny like the  Olympics.The DfT statement added: ldquoThe Permanent Secretary acknowledged in May  that there were cost pressures that the Department and HS Ltd were working to address in line with government policy at the time. Those discussions were active and commercially confidential..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: HS bosses accused of being  ublindsided by contact with reality u

title: obama-criticises-us-virus-response-online-graduation-speech
story: Former president Barack Obama has criticised some officials overseeing the coronavirus response, telling college graduates that the pandemic shows many ldquoarenrsquot even pretending to be in charge.Mr Obama spoke on Show Me Your Walk, HBCU Edition, a two-hour livestreaming event for historically black colleges and universities broadcast on YouTube, Facebook and Twitter.His remarks were surprisingly political and touched on current events beyond the virus and its social and economic impacts.Congratulations to the HBCU Class of ! Michelle and I are so proud of you. As you set out to change the world, wersquoll be the wind at your back. story: The image was posted on social media by close family friend Davie Martin, on behalf of the family, who described the image as ldquopeaceful.The caption alongside the image read: ldquoYes its our wee warrior Mekala outside in the hospital grounds for the first time in god knows how long.ldquoSo emotional looking at this just trying to imagine what Mekala is just sitting there thinking about. A penny for yer thoughts sweetheart. Your one special lassie.Mum Yvonne said: ldquoI wish I knew what your thoughts are toots. So, so proud of you. Very emotional Mummy tonight.Former Preston Lodge High School pupil Mekala, , was travelling through south-east Asia with a friend last autumn when she phoned home complaining of a sore throat.Over the coming days, and after being given antibiotics and painkillers, her condition worsened and she soon ended up in hospital in an induced coma after being diagnosed with bronchial pneumonia.Mekala, who lives in Wallyford, was then transferred to a hospital in Singapore for further treatment.A fundraising page to allow Yvonne and step-dad Jimmy to be by her bedside attracted donations from across East Lothian and beyond, raising over pound,.Mekala was flown back to the UK in November last year and transferred to the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh for further treatment.She was transferred to the Astley Ainslie at the end of March where she is currently receiving rehab.Mekala is said to be doing really well, she is sitting up and had an assisted shower.Speaking to the Courier last month, Jimmy said: ldquoIt is absolutely amazing.ldquoWhen you look at the first photograph back in September of her lying in hospital in Da Nang [Vietnam] and she had a five per cent chance of survival and then look at her now.ldquoShe is still not the same Mekala we know but she is getting there.ldquoShe has got a big smile on her face and we FaceTime every night to keep in touch.ldquoShe is amazing and she can now move a couple of fingers on each hand.It is hoped Mekala will be home for Christmas.Thank you for reading this story. story: Zoologist Donald Malone, a former pupil of Stenton Primary and Dunbar Grammar Schools, will send them to friends at the Sea Mammal Research Unitat the University of St Andrews, who keep databases of seal images and attempt to identy iniduals from them.Mr Malone said: ldquoThis would help gain an idea of the number of both harbour and grey seals around the coast of East Lothian.He added: ldquoThey can also keep a lookout for pups, as harbour seals give birth in June and July and grey seals from September to December. Harbour seal pups shed their whitecoat in the womb before being born and so can be in the water and swim almost straight from birth. Females need to give birth on land though.ldquoGrey seal pups are born with the white lunugo fur and have to stay on land much more until they moult this off around three weeks after giving birth.He saidanyone spots a seal entangled in material such as fishing gear, they should contact British Divers Marine Le Rescuebdmlr.org.uk index.php, which has trained people in East Lothian who will try to capture and free the seal.Mr Malone, who studied zoology at University of Glasgow, has been through this training and has had to aid hundreds of seals all over the world.He was delighted to capture on camera a large group of around  seals, some pregnant, near the Musselburgh lagoons while out for his daily exercise on a cycle from his Edinburgh home.They were hauled out on exposed rocks, just offshore and past the lagoons, heading towards Prestonpans.Mr Malone said: ldquoHarbour seal numbers have actually been in quite drastic decline around Scotland, especially on the east coast, so it was good to see this big group of them.ldquoI am a bit of a fan of seals, having worked on numerous projects on them. story: THE Enormous Turnip is a well known story about the importance of working together.I have written a rhyming version of this traditional tale, which has its origins in Russian folklore.I have shared it with teachers and parents in East Lothian and beyond, and have also created a film, which you can find on my YouTube channel, in which I recite the story, with the written words displayed on the screen.The idea is that hopefully children will create a drawing, painting of a scene or character from the story, and send it in.A photo of a scene being acted out would work too.Itrsquos up to the children to use their creativity in any way they want.I will then add these images onto a new version of the film, where I will tell the story using the childrenrsquos artwork.After the summer I hope to turn all the artwork into a book, in which all the pictures made by the children will be included, along with the rhyming story.My hope is that it can be creative fun, but also that both book and the film could be a positive legacy of the lockdown with a well-known story bringing together children who use their imagination to create something together for posterity.If you are a parent, grandparent, teacher or look after children please do get in touch about how to get involved in this project, and I can send materials and links.Or alternatively, you could just read the story at bedtimeyou fancy.The Enormous Turnip In RhymeOnce there was a family who lived together in a wee houseAn old man, an old woman, their grandchildren, a dog, a cat, and a timid mouse.The house had a garden, so wonderful and green,Where the old man grew vegetables, the best yoursquove ever seen.One day he decided, to plant a turnip seed.So he went to his shed, to get the things he would need:A rake and a hoe, and his gardening gloves.Then he went to the garden, a place that he loves.Carrots and radishes already grew there,So he planted the turnip seed. Can you guess where In a patch of ground that was sunny and brightAnd sheltered from the frost that comes during the night.He watered the seed with his watering can,Then waited for it to grow, that gardening old man.And grow it did, that turnip seed,Under the ground, at an incredible speed.Soon bigger than an apple it grew,Then the size of a football, then the size of two.The turnip got bigger with each passing day,How much would it grow  Nobody could say.It grew from big into huge, and then enormous it became.Never in history had there been a turnip quite the same.At last it was ready to pull out and eat.It will go into a soup, a delicious tasty treat.The old man took hold of the turniprsquos stem, as he knew he should,And then he pulled as hard as he could.The old man heaved and heaved, he really tried.But the turnip wouldnrsquot budge ldquoItrsquos enormous, he cried.He had never seen such a giant turnip in his le!He couldnrsquot pull it by himself, so he called to his we.ldquoMy dear, my dear, please help meTo pull out this turnip, so we can eat it for tea.ldquoHow can I help  she asked the old man,ldquoWhen I pull the turnip, you pull me, as hard as you can.So she It was the wee mouse.She had been watching from her hole in the wallShe was so tiny, and not strong at all.ldquoHow can you help  sneered the cat, looking at the rest.ldquoWell said the mouse, ldquoI will do my best.So the mouse put her feet around the catrsquos tail, and pulled as hard as she could,While the cat pulled the dog, and the dog pulled the boy, and the boy pulled the girl, and the girl pulled the old woman, and the old woman pulled the old man, and the old man pulled the turnip and this time, it was good!They heaved and heaved, they really triedThis time the turnip came out, ldquoHooray they cried.The old man fell back and knocked over the old woman.The old woman fell back and knocked over the girl.The girl fell back and knocked over the boy.The boy fell back and knocked over the dog.The dog fell back and knocked over the cat.The cat fell back and knocked over the mouse.But then they stood up and looked at the turnip theyrsquod pulled out.ldquoWow, itrsquos absolutely enormous! they all said, with a shout.And so that evening they ate it for tea,In a vegetable soup as tasty as can be.The turnip was enormous, it lasted for weeks,So everything they ate, they ate it with neeps.The dog and cat had their share tooAs did the mouse, who had done the best she could do.She made a dference, despite being so small.Perhaps without her, they couldnrsquot have pulled out, the turnip at all.

title: p1-deferrals-u-turn-schools-remain-closed-covid-19
story: Several parents had spoken out in anger after their Primary  deferral funding requests were rejected by the council, which last year had the worst record for approving the applications of any Scottish local authority.This year only two of  applications by parents were approved and of the  refused,  parents appealed.Now the council has said all  cases turned down for funding will be granted the money.However they made it clear the decision was because of the current Covid- pandemic and a review of their policy would be carried out at a later date.One mother told how her children were born two years apart but under the current council policy her youngest son would have had to start P this summer while her oldest, who was born in January, was allowed to defer for a year, was in P.She said: ldquoMy youngest was born at the end of December so they are fully two years apart yet I am not being allowed to defer their start at school and they will be only one year apart in education terms.Current legislation allows parents of children who are born in January and February to automatically receive funding for a delay in starting Primary One until they are five years old.Parents of children born between August and December, who would also start school aged four, can also defer their primary one start for a year but the council can refuse to pay for their nursery care.Last year, East Lothian Council approved  per cent of applications ndash the lowest percentage of any local authority in Scotland. This year the figure fell to less than  per cent.The council also refuses to allow children whose parents opt to keep them home and fund the nursery place themselves to remain in school nurseries.Parents who decide to pay for an additional year of nursery themselves to keep their children out for a year face bills of up to pound, and a hunt for alternative child care places.Another mum who was refused funding said she had initially been supported in her view that her child was too immature to start school by her nursery.But they withdrew that support after pressure from the councilrsquos education department, she said.ldquoThey were told that they couldnrsquot support us because we didnrsquot meet the council policy criteria and withdrew their support, she explained.ldquoOur views meant nothing and the impact on our child meant nothing.And other parents expressed fears that their children were being robbed of nursery experience because they have been in lockdown for some of the vital months they would have had and would have no transition into school.One mum said: Children who start school at -years-old already receive a year less nursery time than those who are older, that has been reduced further by the closure of nurseries.ldquoHow can we ask these young children to go from months at home with their family to suddenly starting primary one with no transition A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoconfirmed they have now agreed to approve all deferral requests for the year ahead.They said: ldquoAs a result of the ongoing closure of schools and nurseries, we have been reviewing applications for deferred entry to P, ahead of session  . Due to the current situation, applications for deferred entry and a further funded year have now been approved. title: yacht-club-takes-measures-help-stay-afloat
story: The yachts should have been craned into the harbour at the start of April and the committee had an ldquoanxious pre-season discussion to figure out safe ways to continue activities as the coronavirus crisis started to unfold.After the full lockdown, with the boats still on dry land, members have been using Skype on a near weekly basis to plan how to keep the club thriving for the foreseeable and long-term future.Former commodore Mark McClelland has urged members to take part in an online sailing race game called Virtual Regatta.One club member will be asked to take part in a Virtual Regatta e-championship against players from other Scottish clubs and then go on to a UK-wide competition.While playing the game, Fisherrow Yacht Clubparticipants also take part in a virtual Friday Night Bar get-together, enjoying a tipple in their own homes while connected to other participants through Zoom.One of the biggest losses to the club programme is the start-of-the season event called Discover Sailing, formerly known as Push the Boat Out, which was due to take place this Saturday, May .Inez Visser, club spokesperson, said: ldquoIt should have been an open day for non-members to try sailing and to look around the facilities in the club premises.ldquoDiscover Sailing has been the most important means to recruit new members in the last few years.ldquoFYC hopes to be able to recreate something similar later in the summer while taking into account necessary hygiene requirements.She explained: ldquoMany FYC members can sail their dinghies or yachts solo or with family members so, from that aspect, sailing can resume as soon as is permitted.ldquoIn addition,local members can come to the beach already dressed to go out on the water, this would free up space in the changing facilities for those who travel from further away.ldquoCurrently, the biggest challenge is figuring out a way to crew the club safety and race committee power boats without breach of the contamination guidelines.ldquoHowever, many resourceful solutions have been devised to protect people from contamination so FYC is hopeful a solution for watersports can be found soon.She added: ldquoWhile not sailing, the committee has been looking at research information published by the sailing umbrella body, Royal Yachting Association , which has analysed age demographics and water participation in general in the last few years.ldquoUsing the information from RYA, the club is looking forward to how its current activities and club facilities, especially club-owned boats, can be dferently managed to suit the needs of the next generation of sailors.ldquoThis includes not only Generations X, Y and Z, but also third age sailors, as the research highlighted that sailing is well suited to older people because the physical demands are not as great as many other sports.ldquoAt this time, FYC is ever mindful that the club premises are a resource, not only for the sailing club, but for other users such as the Musselburgh Athletics Club runners, Eskmuthe Rowing Club, sea cadets, Fisherrow Harbour and Seafront Association and the Cooking Club.!In addition, there are one-off users such as the Musselburgh Festival beach ride out guests and British Divers Marine Le Rescue training day volunteers.ldquoAll of the users have had their activities impacted and we hope that, as soon as possible, they too will be able resume.Thank you for reading this story. title: superhero-primary-school-teacher-message-difference
story: Alison Blevins, a primary four teacher at the school, posted a welcome back message on social media after the Easter holidays.It read: ldquoWelcome back to the summer term. Please donrsquot feel any pressure to complete work in what are challenging circumstances. Irsquod sooner you went outside and enjoyed the good weather. See you in our virtual classroom ready to be curious, positive, successful and respectful.Attached to the message was a picture of Alison as a superhero, with a cape and buildings drawn around her on the ground in chalk.Two days later she shared a lsquofun Friday challengersquo and asked her pupils to dress up as their favourite superhero.She dressed up as Spiderman and her son took several pictures of her climbing and hanging from ious buildings.Alison, who lives in a bungalow, said her son stood on top of a flat piece of roof to take the images ndash but stressed that she doesnrsquot recommend people try the same at home!Inspiration for the pictures came from an art project she did with her primary four class last year, which saw them lie on the ground, draw around their head, then stand back up and add something to the drawing such as a hat or crazy hair.Then the pupil would lie back down and take a photograph. Other ideas for her pictures came from the social media site Pinterest.Alison said: ldquoItrsquos just a dferent spin on it and Irsquom trying to engage with the pupils as much as possible, really. Itrsquos easy and just a bit of fun.One drawing for an image can take as long as a couple of hours to complete. They are also planned out on a piece of paper to make sure they will fit into the space.While some pictures are based on the topic being looked at that week, others, such as her Spiderman picture, are for entertainment.Alison said: ldquoPeople have responded really well. Itrsquos a dferent way of getting in contact with the children and keeping them engaged in their learning.She hopes to post at least one picture a week.Thank you for reading this story.
